BALTIMORE, MD., OCTOBER 19, 1914.

PRICE, FIVE CENTS

WHO'S WHO IN FOOTBALL

CLASS PRESIDENTS ELECTED

$100,000 FOR UNIVERSITY

HOPKINS WINS SECOND GAME

Gridiron Biographies of the Men Who
Compose Squad This Year—Coach
Cates Former Yale Star.

"Joe" Bartlett Chosen to Head Seniors.
Knipp Leads the Juniors; Hall, the
Sophs; Sutton, the Freshies.

G3rdiner M. Lane Makes a Conditional
Bequest in Honor of his Father-inLaw, Professor Gildersleeve.

But Coaches are Disappointed at Team
Weaknesses that Should Not Have
Occurred Getting Under Kicks.

John
Cates has started his
second season as head coach of the
Johns Hopkins squad. He graduated from Yale in 1905, and during his junior and senior years
there he played 'varsity end. His
excellent work at Yale led football
authorities to select him as all-star
end. The year after Mr. Cates
graduated from Yale he was selected head coach for the United
States Naval Academy team, which,
incidentally, was victorious over the
Army that season.
Page Hunter, better known as
"Dutch," is serving his second year
as assistant coach. To the followers of local football he needs no
introduction. Mr. Hunter obtained
much of his knowledge of the
game while a member of the Walbrook and Maryland Athletic Clubs.
His brilliant playing with these
elevens attracted considerable attention, with the result that his services as coach were sought by several teams. Among other elevens,
the Rock Hill squad, in particular,
had unusual success under his
cOaching.
Paul J. Wilkinson came to Hopkins last year and at the end of the
.season was elected captain. During 1909 and 1910 he played tackle
on the Baltimore City College
eleven and in the latter year his
beautiful field goal was responsible
for the defeat of the Polytechnic
Institute. In 1911 and 1912 he
continued to star, playing tackle
with Washington College. Wilkinson's work last year was far above
criticism, and his part in the recent defeat of Stevens indicates
clearly that his ,playing will be a
big factor during ,the remainder of
the season.
H. E. Blair played 'varsity guard
with Western Maryland College in
1912. In the following season his
position was 'varsity tackle. Blair
is a medical student.
Frank Bowers comes from Western Maryland College, where he
played qthrterback. This is Bowers' second year with Hopkins. He
is a graduate student.
John C. Branham first played
football at McDonogh School. During the seasons of 1907, 1908, 1909
and 1910 he played halfback there.
In 1911 he was halfback on the
Washington College squad. Since
then • he has played for the Black
and Blue.
J. V. Brumbaugh was substitute
end at Western Maryland College
during the 1911 and 1912 seasons.

Joe Bartlett was chosen president
of the senior class by unanimous
vote on Friday.
The other 1915 officers, all elected .,nnanimously, are:
Vice-President—William A. Baker, Jr.
Secretary—F. Courtney Tarr.
Treasurer—Emmette R. Spencer.
Sergeant-at-Arms — Thomas F.
Troxell.
The only balloting was done in
the election of the two senior delegates to the Student Council. William A. Baker, Jr., secretary of last
year's Council, was re-elected, and
Wilmer Brinton, Jr., was chosen as
his colleague on the Board.

By COACH JOHN M. CATES.

Although Hopkins won its second game of the season by defeating Washington College by a score
of 14 to 6, the game as a whole
was disappointing to the coaches.
This statement is made in the belief that Hopkins alumni desire to
know the real situation with respect
to the team. We can be elated over
the winning of a game, but we
should not be blind to the weaknesses of our team developed by
the game. Of course, the season is
still young and we cannot expect at
this stage either finished execution
of offensive play or impregnable defensive tactics against the offense of
the opponents. In other words, it
is too early to expect a co-ordinated
team offense or defense. It is not
too early, however, to expect individual men to do well certain
specified acts which must be done
well if team play is ever to be perfected.
The disappointing feature of the
game rested in the failure of men
to do the things which we know
they know how to do and which
they failed to do for some unaccountable psychological reason. For
example, every man knows enough
about the game to realize the importance of running down the field
under a kick-off or punt. Not once
in the game did the team as a whole,
or an individual for that matter,
really cover a kick. The reason for
this can only be attributed to some
mental . deficiency which coaches
cannot supply. Failure to hear or
comprehend the simplest signals;
failure to tackle or hold a player
when tackled; failure to spill an
opponent when the only requisite
for its accomplishment is ability to
fall down in front of him, are all
chargeable to the same deficiency.
It's a question of mental attitude.
Each player must help in the working out of his own salvation. Until
our players develop a real desire to
accomplish a purpose so strong that
it will not be denied we cannot hope
for real success. This desire is a
personal matter. In some places it
is called "spirit." *Whatever it is it
must be worked out by the individual.
Hopkins showed flashes of real
form in Saturday's game, but it
was not sustained. We were very
fortunate to win. Too much praise
cannot be accorded the Washington
College team for its slap-dash,
slam-bang style of play. With a
line defense that was really good
and an offense on the part of a few

While the schedule of the public
lecture courses is not yet quite complete, the principal lectureships have
been arranged. The University is
still in communication with several
other men, and some interesting
announcements are to be expected
in a few weeks.
The most interesting announcement from the office is that the
Turnbull Lectureship on English
Literature, given last year by Dr.
Kittredge, of Harvard, will be delivered during the spring by Sir
Walter Raleigh, professor of English literature at Oxford University. Sir Walter is a distinguished
English scholar with a large reputation. Some apprehension is felt
by the University authorities, however, that he may be at the front
with a regiment. He has not been
heard from for some time, and,
therefore, neither his subject, nor
the dates of his lectures are known.
Dr. William A. Dunning, former
president. of the American Historical Association, and Lieber professor of history and political philosophy at Columbia University, will
deliver the Schouler Lectures, six
in number, some time in January.
These lectures were given by Dr.
Charles Francis Adams last winter,
and drew large and enthusiastic
audiences. Dr. Dunning is said to
be a most interesting speaker, and •
very witty. He is a great favorite
at Columbia. His subject has not
been announced, but it is known
that it will not deal with his historical specialty, "Civil War Reconstruction."
The Albert Shaw lectures, which
are given yearly before the Historical and Political Seminaries, will be
in the hands of Dr. C. W. Alvord
of the University of Illinois: He
will devote the entire series of ten
lectures to the subject of the diplomatic negotiations in regard to the
West during the French and Indian
and the Revolutionary wars. This
course will be given some time in
November, and although designed
especially for the seminaries, it will
be open to any students who may
desire to attend.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS—LETTER, OCTOBER 19, 1914.

"fts

DR. GOODNOW GETS A DEGREE

SPRING SCHEDULES BEING MADE

New President is One of Many Distinguished Men Honored by Brown
University at its Anniversary.

The Track and Lacrosse Dates Will Be
Practically the Same as Last Year.
Armory Meet in February.

Dr. Frank Johnson Goodnow,
President of the University, was
awarded the honorary degreeof
doctor of laws at the celebration
of the one hundred and fiftieth anniversary of the founding of Brown
University on Thursday at Providence, R. I.
The honor was not a new one
for Dr. Goodnow, as he had already
been made a doctor of laws by his
alma mater (Amherst, 1897; Columbia, 1904; and Harvard, 1909).
It is, however, the first _degree that
has been conferred upon him since
he has taken up his duties at Hopkins.
President Goodnow, together with
President Schurman, of Cornell,
and others, later addressed the students of Brown University in the
college chapel. The former constitutional adviser of the republic of
China told of his experiences in
that country and of the character
of the work being done by students
there.
The recipients of degrees were
statesmen, diplomats, jurists and
educators. Among them were:
Doctor of Laws — William H.
Taft, former President of the
1. nited States;
Romulo S. Naon,
ambassador from Argentina; Frederico Alfonso Pezel, minister from
Peru; Le Baron B. Colt, United
States Senator; Andrew Carnegie;
Profegsor John Bassett Moore of
Columbia University; Presidents
Thomass of Bryn Mawr College,
Goodnow of Johns Hopkins, Lowell of Harvard, Taylor of William
and Mary, Hibben of Princeton,
Schurman of Cornell, Hadley of
Yale and Butler of Columbia.
Doctor of Literature — Herbert
Putnam, librarian of Congress;
James Ford Rhodes, historian; and
Archdeacon William Cunningham
of Cambridge
University.

The •track and lacrosse schedules
for the coming season, now in act
of preparation by the- managers, are
assuming shape.
The track "engagements" this
year, according to Manager C. E.
Deems, will not differ materially
from those of last season. The armory meet will come, as usual, during the middle of February. The
regular season, however, opens later
in the year, probably the last of
April and extending through the
latter part of May.
During this period, there will be
weekly meets with various colleges
and athletic associations — t w o
prominent meets being those held
with Navy and Virginia. The
South Atlantic Intercollegiate meet
will come during the early part of
May.
Manager H. W. Woodward is
arranging a lacrosse schedule that
- will include the same "twelves"
that have been met in years heretofore. The dates of play are not
yet available.
In the interest of the Hopkins
lacrosse team, Tom Troxell, captain, and Bill Schmeisser, graduate
adviser, went to New York last
Saturday to attend the annual meeting of the Intercollegiate Lacrosse
League of America.

Some Minor Changes Made to Modernize Game and Eliminate Rough
Play at Annual Convention.

College lacrosse rules were revised and modernized. by the delegates to the tenth annual convention of the United States Intercollegiate Lacrosse League on Saturday at the Park Avenue Hotel, New
York City, and an effort will be
made to popularize the sport by introducing it to prep schools. The
committee appointed last year to
revise the playing rules recommended several important changes
which received the approval of the
delegates. Matches have in the past
been played according to rules
adopted ten years ago, and these
were not stringent enough for the
present game.
Under the revised rules the captain must be a playing member of
the team, and the referee has increased powers, which will serve to
eliminate many objectionable features of the former playing rules
and keep the game free from unnecessary roughness..
The experiment tried last year
of selecting a chief referee to designite referees for all games was
found to be so satisfactory that it
will be continued this year.
It was decided to play the game
for the open championship between
the northern and southern divisions
on May 22, 1915; the location to be
determined by the winners of the
two divisions. The divisions follow:
Northern—Harvard, Cornell, Stevens and Hobart; southern—Lehigh, Johns Hopkins and Swarthmore.
The annual election resulted as
follows: President, Kenneth B. ,
Day (Harvard); Vice-President,
Milton Erlanger (Johns Hopkins);.
Secretary and Treasurer, R. C.
Campbell (Stevens); Member at
Large, C. E. Marsters (Harvard).
The following representatives attended the convention: Harvard,
C. E. Marsters and J. Garland; Lehigh, H. R. Walters and E. P.
Humphrey; Stevens, R. C. Campbell and John S. Beck; Johns Hopkins, William C. Schmeisser and
Thomas F. Troxell; Swarthmore,
J. H. Taylor and Frederick C. Dennis; Cornell, Rodney Walbridge
and A. A. Blue; former President
John R. Broomwell (Swarthmore)
and former Vice-President W. J.
Finlay, Jr. (Cornell).

Buy-a-Bale Movement Appeals to Texans

Engineering students at the University of Texas contributed $50 to
buy a bale of cotton.
*

*

Belgians to Have "Royal Tailored Look."

The appeal for old clothes by
the Princeton Chapter of the Red
Cross Society was •met with unhoped for generosity. Six large
packing boxes and two barrels of
clothing were collected and dispatched from Princeton for Belgium.
*

*

*

Virginia Takes Cotton for Tuition.

According to reports, the dean
of the University of Virginia is instructed by the Board of Visitors
to receive cotton in lieu of money
in payment of tuition fees. After
a heated discussion the board decided that for the current session
students would be allowed to pay
all of their tuition with United
States warehouse receipts, such receipts to be accepted at a rate not
to exceed ten cents a pound for the
cotton.
Because of the present condition
of the cotton market, a great number of students residing in the cotton belt were about to be deprived
of the privilege of registering this
year.
Virginia has the distinction of being the first to come to the aid of
students in such a manner. In•fact,
it is believed to be unique in the history of educational institutions.
*

*

*

Carnegie Tech Men Use Too Much Sugar

If the Beanery is to be conducted
on as economical a plan as. possible,
it is essential that every student do
his share to keep down the expense.
An example of lack of thought
on the part of the students is in the
use of the novel type of sugar bowl
placed on the tables. This type
was designed to do away with the
chance of a student dipping his individual spoon into the bowl. However, the new bowls are used while
the user is thinking over difficult
calculus or other problems, the
sugar being allowed to pour out
indefinitely. Enough sugar has
been used up lately to run a large
hotel. It was originally calculated
that twelve pounds a day would be
sufficient, but instead the amount
averages about twenty-six pounds ;
the coffee cups coming out to the
washing machine with a half an
inch layer remaining on the bottom.
This is food waste, and it also increases the difficulty of washing.
It is to be hoped that the patrons
of the Beanery will be more careful in this seemingly small, but still,
when totalled, very large item. The
thoughtful interest of every student
will be necessary in order to make
the Beanery the success that its
sponsors wish for it. — The Carnegie Tech Tarban.

Third of the "Special Units" for General
Hospital Work Erected as Part of
the Hopkins Equipment.

The new James Buchanan Brady
Urological Institute of the Medical School was opened on October 9.
The institute, which is for the
study and treatment of kidney and
bladder diseases, is the third of the
"special units" for general hospital
work that have been erected to
form part of the Johns Hopkins
equipment. The cost of construction, amounting to more than $2o0,000, has been borne by Mr. Brady.
The laboratories will be the most
complete of their kind in the world.
The building is seven stories in
height.
Mr. Brady, a prominent New
Yorker, was ill for two months in
the spring and summer of 1912, but
after undergoing an operation at
the Johns Hopkins Hospital he recovered. The urological institute
is a practical demonstration of his
gratitude for the treatment he received from the Hopkins surgeons.
After he had recovered and returned home he wrote the following letter to Dr. Hugh H. Young,
who attended him:

we have had, and:pursuant to the intention heretofore expressed by me, I

from time to time, as it may be required (the total not to exceed the sum

I would thank you to either deliver
or communicate the contents of this
letter to the Board of Trustees of the
Johns Hopkins Hospital.
Very truly yours,
JAMES BUCHANAN BRADY.

Anent the "Freshman Regulations."
October 15, 1914.
To the Editor of THE NEWS-LETTER:
SIR—There is a phrase in the
new "freshman regulations" which
specifies that "freshmen shall occupy seats in the rooters' section
at all games at Homewood unless
accompanied by guests."
The last clause of this regulation
is interpreted correctly by THE
NEws-LETTER in its last issue when
it substitutes in its stead "lady
friends."
This regulation cannot be interpreted to allow two freshmen
to sit together as student and guest
in any other portion of the stands
at Homewood, except the rooters'
section.
I call attention to this fact: first,
because I do not think the regulation clearly explains itself; and,
second, because I saw the regulation violated at a recent game by
several parties.
This regulation must be enforced,
and I voice the sentiment expressed
by a correspondent in last week's
column that there is no use to make
rules without specifying a penalty.
Yours truly,
A SOPHIE.

To dread no eye and to suspect
no tongue is the greatest prerogative of innocence; an exception
granted only to invariable virtue.
—Johnson.

John
Cates has started his
second season as head coach of the
Johns Hopkins squad. He graduated from Yale in 1905, and during his junior and senior years
there he played 'varsity end. His
excellent work at Yale led football
authorities to select him as all-star
end. The year after Mr. Cates
graduated from Yale he was selected head coach for the United
States Naval Academy team, which,
incidentally, was victorious over the
Army that season.
Page Hunter, better known as
"Dutch," is serving his second year
as assistant coach. To the followers of local football he needs no
introduction. Mr. Hunter obtained
much of his knowledge of the
game while a member of the Walbrook and Maryland Athletic Clubs.
His brilliant playing with these
elevens attracted considerable attention, with the result that his services as coach were sought by several teams. Among other elevens,
the Rock Hill squad, in particular,
had unusual success under his
cOaching.
Paul J. Wilkinson came to Hopkins last year and at the end of the
.season was elected captain. During 1909 and 1910 he played tackle
on the Baltimore City College
eleven and in the latter year his
beautiful field goal was responsible
for the defeat of the Polytechnic
Institute. In 1911 and 1912 he
continued to star, playing tackle
with Washington College. Wilkinson's work last year was far above
criticism, and his part in the recent defeat of Stevens indicates
clearly that his ,playing will be a
big factor during ,the remainder of
the season.
H. E. Blair played 'varsity guard
with Western Maryland College in
1912. In the following season his
position was 'varsity tackle. Blair
is a medical student.
Frank Bowers comes from Western Maryland College, where he
played qthrterback. This is Bowers' second year with Hopkins. He
is a graduate student.
John C. Branham first played
football at McDonogh School. During the seasons of 1907, 1908, 1909
and 1910 he played halfback there.
In 1911 he was halfback on the
Washington College squad. Since
then • he has played for the Black
and Blue.
J. V. Brumbaugh was substitute
end at Western Maryland College
during the 1911 and 1912 seasons.

By COACH JOHN M. CATES.

Although Hopkins won its second game of the season by defeating Washington College by a score
of 14 to 6, the game as a whole
was disappointing to the coaches.
This statement is made in the belief that Hopkins alumni desire to
know the real situation with respect
to the team. We can be elated over
the winning of a game, but we
should not be blind to the weaknesses of our team developed by
the game. Of course, the season is
still young and we cannot expect at
this stage either finished execution
of offensive play or impregnable defensive tactics against the offense of
the opponents. In other words, it
is too early to expect a co-ordinated
team offense or defense. It is not
too early, however, to expect individual men to do well certain
specified acts which must be done
well if team play is ever to be perfected.
The disappointing feature of the
game rested in the failure of men
to do the things which we know
they know how to do and which
they failed to do for some unaccountable psychological reason. For
example, every man knows enough
about the game to realize the importance of running down the field
under a kick-off or punt. Not once
in the game did the team as a whole,
or an individual for that matter,
really cover a kick. The reason for
this can only be attributed to some
mental . deficiency which coaches
cannot supply. Failure to hear or
comprehend the simplest signals;
failure to tackle or hold a player
when tackled; failure to spill an
opponent when the only requisite
for its accomplishment is ability to
fall down in front of him, are all
chargeable to the same deficiency.
It's a question of mental attitude.
Each player must help in the working out of his own salvation. Until
our players develop a real desire to
accomplish a purpose so strong that
it will not be denied we cannot hope
for real success. This desire is a
personal matter. In some places it
is called "spirit." *Whatever it is it
must be worked out by the individual.
Hopkins showed flashes of real
form in Saturday's game, but it
was not sustained. We were very
fortunate to win. Too much praise
cannot be accorded the Washington
College team for its slap-dash,
slam-bang style of play. With a
line defense that was really good
and an offense on the part of a few

While the schedule of the public
lecture courses is not yet quite complete, the principal lectureships have
been arranged. The University is
still in communication with several
other men, and some interesting
announcements are to be expected
in a few weeks.
The most interesting announcement from the office is that the
Turnbull Lectureship on English
Literature, given last year by Dr.
Kittredge, of Harvard, will be delivered during the spring by Sir
Walter Raleigh, professor of English literature at Oxford University. Sir Walter is a distinguished
English scholar with a large reputation. Some apprehension is felt
by the University authorities, however, that he may be at the front
with a regiment. He has not been
heard from for some time, and,
therefore, neither his subject, nor
the dates of his lectures are known.
Dr. William A. Dunning, former
president. of the American Historical Association, and Lieber professor of history and political philosophy at Columbia University, will
deliver the Schouler Lectures, six
in number, some time in January.
These lectures were given by Dr.
Charles Francis Adams last winter,
and drew large and enthusiastic
audiences. Dr. Dunning is said to
be a most interesting speaker, and •
very witty. He is a great favorite
at Columbia. His subject has not
been announced, but it is known
that it will not deal with his historical specialty, "Civil War Reconstruction."
The Albert Shaw lectures, which
are given yearly before the Historical and Political Seminaries, will be
in the hands of Dr. C. W. Alvord
of the University of Illinois: He
will devote the entire series of ten
lectures to the subject of the diplomatic negotiations in regard to the
West during the French and Indian
and the Revolutionary wars. This
course will be given some time in
November, and although designed
especially for the seminaries, it will
be open to any students who may
desire to attend.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS—LETTER, OCTOBER 19, 1914.

DR. GOODNOW GETS A DEGREE

SPRING SCHEDULES BEING MADE

New President is One of Many Distinguished Men Honored by Brown
University at its Anniversary.

The Track and Lacrosse Dates Will Be
Practically the Same as Last Year.
Armory Meet in February.

Dr. Frank Johnson Goodnow,
President of the University, was
awarded the honorary degreeof
doctor of laws at the celebration
of the one hundred and fiftieth anniversary of the founding of Brown
University on Thursday at Providence, R. I.
The honor was not a new one
for Dr. Goodnow, as he had already
been made a doctor of laws by his
alma mater (Amherst, 1897; Columbia, 1904; and Harvard, 1909).
It is, however, the first _degree that
has been conferred upon him since
he has taken up his duties at Hopkins.
President Goodnow, together with
President Schurman, of Cornell,
and others, later addressed the students of Brown University in the
college chapel. The former constitutional adviser of the republic of
China told of his experiences in
that country and of the character
of the work being done by students
there.
The recipients of degrees were
statesmen, diplomats, jurists and
educators. Among them were:
Doctor of Laws — William H.
Taft, former President of the
1. nited States;
Romulo S. Naon,
ambassador from Argentina; Frederico Alfonso Pezel, minister from
Peru; Le Baron B. Colt, United
States Senator; Andrew Carnegie;
Profegsor John Bassett Moore of
Columbia University; Presidents
Thomass of Bryn Mawr College,
Goodnow of Johns Hopkins, Lowell of Harvard, Taylor of William
and Mary, Hibben of Princeton,
Schurman of Cornell, Hadley of
Yale and Butler of Columbia.
Doctor of Literature — Herbert
Putnam, librarian of Congress;
James Ford Rhodes, historian; and
Archdeacon William Cunningham
of Cambridge
University.

The •track and lacrosse schedules
for the coming season, now in act
of preparation by the- managers, are
assuming shape.
The track "engagements" this
year, according to Manager C. E.
Deems, will not differ materially
from those of last season. The armory meet will come, as usual, during the middle of February. The
regular season, however, opens later
in the year, probably the last of
April and extending through the
latter part of May.
During this period, there will be
weekly meets with various colleges
and athletic associations — t w o
prominent meets being those held
with Navy and Virginia. The
South Atlantic Intercollegiate meet
will come during the early part of
May.
Manager H. W. Woodward is
arranging a lacrosse schedule that
- will include the same "twelves"
that have been met in years heretofore. The dates of play are not
yet available.
In the interest of the Hopkins
lacrosse team, Tom Troxell, captain, and Bill Schmeisser, graduate
adviser, went to New York last
Saturday to attend the annual meeting of the Intercollegiate Lacrosse
League of America.

Some Minor Changes Made to Modernize Game and Eliminate Rough
Play at Annual Convention.

College lacrosse rules were revised and modernized. by the delegates to the tenth annual convention of the United States Intercollegiate Lacrosse League on Saturday at the Park Avenue Hotel, New
York City, and an effort will be
made to popularize the sport by introducing it to prep schools. The
committee appointed last year to
revise the playing rules recommended several important changes
which received the approval of the
delegates. Matches have in the past
been played according to rules
adopted ten years ago, and these
were not stringent enough for the
present game.
Under the revised rules the captain must be a playing member of
the team, and the referee has increased powers, which will serve to
eliminate many objectionable features of the former playing rules
and keep the game free from unnecessary roughness..
The experiment tried last year
of selecting a chief referee to designite referees for all games was
found to be so satisfactory that it
will be continued this year.
It was decided to play the game
for the open championship between
the northern and southern divisions
on May 22, 1915; the location to be
determined by the winners of the
two divisions. The divisions follow:
Northern—Harvard, Cornell, Stevens and Hobart; southern—Lehigh, Johns Hopkins and Swarthmore.
The annual election resulted as
follows: President, Kenneth B. ,
Day (Harvard); Vice-President,
Milton Erlanger (Johns Hopkins);.
Secretary and Treasurer, R. C.
Campbell (Stevens); Member at
Large, C. E. Marsters (Harvard).
The following representatives attended the convention: Harvard,
C. E. Marsters and J. Garland; Lehigh, H. R. Walters and E. P.
Humphrey; Stevens, R. C. Campbell and John S. Beck; Johns Hopkins, William C. Schmeisser and
Thomas F. Troxell; Swarthmore,
J. H. Taylor and Frederick C. Dennis; Cornell, Rodney Walbridge
and A. A. Blue; former President
John R. Broomwell (Swarthmore)
and former Vice-President W. J.
Finlay, Jr. (Cornell).

THE BRADY INSTITUTE OPENED
AT OTHER COLLEGES
Buy-a-Bale Movement Appeals to Texans

Engineering students at the University of Texas contributed $50 to
buy a bale of cotton.
*

*

*

Belgians to Have "Royal Tailored Look."

The appeal for old clothes by
the Princeton Chapter of the Red
Cross Society was •met with unhoped for generosity. Six large
packing boxes and two barrels of
clothing were collected and dispatched from Princeton for Belgium.
*

*

*

Virginia Takes Cotton for Tuition.

According to reports, the dean
of the University of Virginia is instructed by the Board of Visitors
to receive cotton in lieu of money
in payment of tuition fees. After
a heated discussion the board decided that for the current session
students would be allowed to pay
all of their tuition with United
States warehouse receipts, such receipts to be accepted at a rate not
to exceed ten cents a pound for the
cotton.
Because of the present condition
of the cotton market, a great number of students residing in the cotton belt were about to be deprived
of the privilege of registering this
year.
Virginia has the distinction of being the first to come to the aid of
students in such a manner. In•fact,
it is believed to be unique in the history of educational institutions.
*

*

*

Carnegie Tech Men Use Too Much Sugar

If the Beanery is to be conducted
on as economical a plan as. possible,
it is essential that every student do
his share to keep down the expense.
An example of lack of thought
on the part of the students is in the
use of the novel type of sugar bowl
placed on the tables. This type
was designed to do away with the
chance of a student dipping his individual spoon into the bowl. However, the new bowls are used while
the user is thinking over difficult
calculus or other problems, the
sugar being allowed to pour out
indefinitely. Enough sugar has
been used up lately to run a large
hotel. It was originally calculated
that twelve pounds a day would be
sufficient, but instead the amount
averages about twenty-six pounds ;
the coffee cups coming out to the
washing machine with a half an
inch layer remaining on the bottom.
This is food waste, and it also increases the difficulty of washing.
It is to be hoped that the patrons
of the Beanery will be more careful in this seemingly small, but still,
when totalled, very large item. The
thoughtful interest of every student
will be necessary in order to make
the Beanery the success that its
sponsors wish for it. — The Carnegie Tech Tarban.

Third of the "Special Units" for General
Hospital Work Erected as Part of
the Hopkins Equipment.

The new James Buchanan Brady
Urological Institute of the Medical School was opened on October 9.
The institute, which is for the
study and treatment of kidney and
bladder diseases, is the third of the
"special units" for general hospital
work that have been erected to
form part of the Johns Hopkins
equipment. The cost of construction, amounting to more than $2o0,000, has been borne by Mr. Brady.
The laboratories will be the most
complete of their kind in the world.
The building is seven stories in
height.
Mr. Brady, a prominent New
Yorker, was ill for two months in
the spring and summer of 1912, but
after undergoing an operation at

James A. Brady,

October 10, 1912.
Dr. H. H. Young, Johns Hopkins Hospital,
Baltimore, Md.
Dear Dr. Young:
Confirming the various conversations
we have had, and:pursuant to the intention heretofore expressed by me, I
beg to advise you that it is. my purpose, commencing on or about the first
day of April next, to supply the money
from time to time, as it may be required (the total not to exceed the sum
of $200,000), with which to erect and
complete a building as part of the
Johns Hopkins Hospital in the City of
Baltimore to be devoted to the advancement of the science and practice of
urology and to be known as the James
Buchanan Brady Institute of Urology.
This building to be constructed and organized in general accordance with the
plans shown me last spring by you,
providing for a building with a distinct front on Monument street and
connecting with the surgical building
and out - patient genito - urinary dispensary.
Upon the completion of the said
building I will contribute $15,000 annually during my life to its support
and maintenance. I have also made a
provision in my will leaving a substantial sum to the institute.
I would thank you to either deliver
or communicate the contents of this
letter to the Board of Trustees of the
Johns Hopkins Hospital.
Very truly yours,
JAMES BUCHANAN BRADY.

Anent the "Freshman Regulations."
October 15, 1914.
To the Editor of THE NEWS-LETTER:
SIR—There is a phrase in the
new "freshman regulations" which
specifies that "freshmen shall occupy seats in the rooters' section
at all games at Homewood unless
accompanied by guests."
The last clause of this regulation
is interpreted correctly by THE
NEws-LETTER in its last issue when
it substitutes in its stead "lady
friends."
This regulation cannot be interpreted to allow two freshmen
to sit together as student and guest
in any other portion of the stands
at Homewood, except the rooters'
section.
I call attention to this fact: first,
because I do not think the regulation clearly explains itself; and,
second, because I saw the regulation violated at a recent game by
several parties.
This regulation must be enforced,
and I voice the sentiment expressed
by a correspondent in last week's
column that there is no use to make
rules without specifying a penalty.
Yours truly,
A SOPHIE.
Courage of Innocence.

To dread no eye and to suspect
no tongue is the greatest prerogative of innocence; an exception
granted only to invariable virtue.
—Johnson.
